Competency: Interacts appropriately with diverse groups of people
Skill: Interacts respectfully and appropriately with people from a wide variety of backgrounds & life experiences. Understands and adapts to cultural differences in communication, relational, presentational and other styles/preferences and norms. Is self-aware of own cultural styles/preferences and norms. Understand how one's own background (cultural, socio-economic, generational, educational, etc.) impacts how one perceives other people and situations. Regularly seeks out opportunities to learn about the histories, cultures, experiences, etc. of people from a wide variety of backgrounds & life experiences.
Resource Description: Highly regarded facilitated dialogues to help participants learn about and dismantle systemic racism, build strategies for resistance and alternatives, and promote healing.

Competency: Interacts appropriately with diverse groups of people
Skill: Interacts respectfully and appropriately with people from a wide variety of backgrounds & life experiences. Understands and adapts to cultural differences in communication, relational, presentational and other styles/preferences and norms. Is self-aware of own cultural styles/preferences and norms. Understand how one's own background (cultural, socio-economic, generational, educational, etc.) impacts how one perceives other people and situations. Regularly seeks out opportunities to learn about the histories, cultures, experiences, etc. of people from a wide variety of backgrounds & life experiences.
Resource Description: NLI offers a variety of highly praised workshops related to building diverse relationships, cultivating diverse participation and leadership, leveraging the power of diverse teams, and more. Check website for information on upcoming workshops or email <natural.leaders@cornell.edu>.

Competency: Interacts appropriately with diverse groups of people
Skill: Interacts respectfully and appropriately with people from a wide variety of backgrounds & life experiences. Understands and adapts to cultural differences in communication, relational, presentational and other styles/preferences and norms. Is self-aware of own cultural styles/preferences and norms. Regularly seeks out opportunities to learn about the histories, cultures, experiences, etc. of people from a wide variety of backgrounds & life experiences.
Resource Description: Opening Doors (offered on the Cornell campus) is a highly valued, time-tested workshop model for creating a climate for constructive change on diversity for individuals and organizations. Opening Doors offers a foundational understanding of diversity that supports staff in developing a deeper awareness, understanding and skills for effectively working across differences.

Competency: Understands how achieving equity and inclusion requires a combination of personal behaviors, organizational practices, and institutionalized policies.
Skill: Understands how inequity is created in our societies by a combination of personal attitudes and behaviors, organizational practices, and "institutionalized" policies. Understands the historical roots of these inequities and how they continue into the present. Has strategies for addressing and changing those in one's work at CCETC.
Resource Description: CCE Administration has multiple resources for understanding and developing relationships with diverse communities.

Competency: Can build relationships with diverse communities.
Skill: Able to build trusted relationships with people from diverse cultural and economic background. Has sufficient knowledge of diverse cultural expectations and norms to be successful.
Resource Description: CCE Administration has multiple resources for understanding and developing relationships with diverse communities.

Skill: Recruits, hires/appoints, supervises and retains diverse staff and volunteers. Knows best practices for recruiting and hiring for diversity. Competency: Successfully contributes to an inclusive organizational culture

The registration cost for the workshop is $495 and includes all workshop materials, lodging and food.

Competency: Knows CCETC financial policies and procedures
Skill: Understands and can carry out CCETC financial policies and procedures (e.g., recording hours work, expense reporting, mail codes, cash handling, tax-exempt forms, out-of-pocket expense & mileage reimbursement, in-house supply charging, check and cash advance requests, and CCETC Visa card.)

Competency: Develops budgets and track expenses

Competency: Writes successful grant proposals

Resource Title: Human Services Coalition of Tompkins County (HSC-TC)
Resource Description: HSC-TC offers a variety of workshops throughout the year Check their website for schedule and cost.  Example: Grantwriting Basics.

Competency: Writes successful grant proposals
Skill: Able to identify relevant funding entities and to develop and write successful grant proposals. Knows how to research and identify appropriate funding prospects. Understands what funders are looking for in grant proposals. Understands the relationship-building aspects of the grant-making process. Knows the differences in applying for funding from private foundations, community foundations, government agencies, etc.
Resource Description: Useful free e-book by local grantwriter & grantwriting instructor Jana Hextor. She also offers a free e-newsletter and blog with tips.

Competency: Writes successful grant proposals
Skill: Able to identify relevant funding entities and to develop and write successful grant proposals. Knows how to research and identify appropriate funding prospects. Understands what funders are looking for in grant proposals. Understands the relationship-building aspects of the grant-making process. Knows the differences in applying for funding from private foundations, community foundations, government agencies, etc.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Example: Writing Proposals. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Writes successful grant proposals
Skill: Able to identify relevant funding entities and to develop and write successful grant proposals. Knows how to research and identify appropriate funding prospects. Understands what funders are looking for in grant proposals. Understands the relationship-building aspects of the grant-making process. Knows the differences in applying for funding from private foundations, community foundations, government agencies, etc.
Resource Description: Cornell's Mann Library has many resources, including links to guides for writing federal and state grants, and e-books that can be downloaded and read.

Competency: Writes successful grant proposals
Skill: Able to identify relevant funding entities and to develop and write successful grant proposals. Knows how to research and identify appropriate funding prospects. Understands what funders are looking for in grant proposals. Understands the relationship-building aspects of the grant-making process. Knows the differences in applying for funding from private foundations, community foundations, government agencies, etc.
Resource Description: The Foundation Center has a tremendous amount of online resources, including online funder databases, research tools, and skill-building resources, webinars and other training related to proposal writing, fundraising, organizational sustainability, and management.

Competency: Writes successful grant proposals
Skill: Able to identify relevant funding entities and to develop and write successful grant proposals. Knows how to research and identify appropriate funding prospects. Understands what funders are looking for in grant proposals. Understands the relationship-building aspects of the grant-making process. Knows the differences in applying for funding from private foundations, community foundations, government agencies, etc.
Resource Description: GrantSpace (an offshoot of the Foundation Center) has a huge variety of webinars, podcasts, e-courses, regional trainings, and printed resources related to all aspects of non-profit fundraising, including finding donors, proposal writing, fundraising, starting non-profits, and more. Many resources are free; others have a fee.

Competency: Writes successful grant proposals
Skill: Able to identify relevant funding entities and to develop and write successful grant proposals. Knows how to research and identify appropriate funding prospects. Understands what funders are looking for in grant proposals. Understands the relationship-building aspects of the grant-making process. Knows the differences in applying for funding from private foundations, community foundations, government agencies, etc.
Resource Title: Tompkins County Grants Development and Management Center
Resource Description: This Tompkins County government grants development web portal has information on federal, state and private foundation grants, along with many links to excellent resources on grant preparation tools and related training. Most resources are free and available to the public.

Competency: Is able to plan and implement other financial resource development efforts
Skill: Able to develop financial resources through fundraising campaigns, major donor development, business sponsorships, etc.
Resource Title: Human Services Coalition of Tompkins County (HSC-TC)
Resource Description: HSC-TC offers a variety of workshops throughout the year.  Check their website for schedule and cost.  Example: How to Ask for a Lot of Money

Competency: Is able to plan and implement other financial resource development efforts
Skill: Able to develop financial resources through fundraising campaigns, major donor development, business sponsorships, etc.
Resource Description: The Foundation Center has a lot of skill-building information related to seeking funding from foundations, corporations and individual donors (along with info on proposal writing, organizational sustainability, and management.

Competency: Assists with financial decision-making.
Skill: Ensures development of easily accessed and up-to-date resources for standard CCETC budget expenses for use in budget planning and grantwriting. Assists staff with financial management issues and ensures compliance.
Resource Description: Grant writing resources include Planning your Program for Proposal Writing and Being Strategic with Grant Writing.

Competency: Develops multi-program budgets and financial projections
Skill: Carries out program area and association-wide budgeting, financial projections, and fiscal management.
Resource Description: Podcasts, webinars, e-courses and written materials on a variety of non-profit management topics, including business planning, strategy development, fundraising, organizational sustainability, and leadership and management. Some free; some have a fee.

Competency: Effectively uses standard computer programs
Skill: Effectively uses basic computer programs/applications (e.g., Word, Excel, Powerpoint) to accomplish project goals.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many computer application topics from basic to advanced. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Effectively uses standard computer programs
Skill: Effectively uses basic computer programs/applications (e.g., Word, Excel, Powerpoint) to accomplish project goals.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Examples: Using Your Desktop Computer and Devices Safely, Computing Fundamentals (book), Excel 2016, Microsoft Office 2013 Beginning Word.  Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Effectively uses standard computer programs
Skill: Effectively uses basic computer programs/applications (e.g., Word, Excel, Powerpoint) to accomplish project goals.
Resource Description: Tompkins Cortland Community College offers courses on: Keyboarding for computers, Introduction to Word Processing, Introduction to Spreadsheets, Introduction to Databases, Presentation Software, and Web Page Design.  5 week courses with TC3 enrollment and costs associated.  Courses are in person or web based.  Student choice.

Competency: Effectively uses standard computer programs
Skill: Effectively uses basic computer programs/applications (e.g., Word, Excel, Powerpoint) to accomplish project goals.
Resource Description: In person training through Cornell that covers basic computer use (Mouse settings and use, navigating Windows, file management, Control Panel, printing, etc.).  This training may be standardized for a group.  Minimum 10, max 15.  Cost is approximately $150-$200 per person depending on numbers.

Competency: Effectively uses standard Internet-based applications
Skill: Edits existing web pages to update information, graphics, photos, etc. Understands how to use social networking to reach target audiences.
Resource Description: The Communications Resources contain the following recorded webinar:  You've got Twitter and Facebook Accounts, Now What?

Competency: Develops online information
Skill: Creates new web pages to provide new information, graphics, photos, etc. Uses social media to provide information in designated subject areas.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Examples: Building Dynamic Web Sites, Digital Marketing: Getting to the Customer. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Develops online information
Skill: Creates new web pages to provide new information, graphics, photos, etc. Uses social media to provide information in designated subject areas.
Resource Description: Webinars, e-courses, podcasts and written information related to developing a social media stratety, social media storytelling, and more. Some free; some with a fee.

Skill: Creates new web pages to provide new information, graphics, photos, etc. Uses social media to provide information in designated subject areas.

Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many technology-based tools. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many technology-based tools. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Is able to use established systems for organizing own schedules and priorities
Skill: Uses established systems to organize and track information (files, appointment calendars, etc…). Understands priorities and keeps clear records of completed and pending activities. Participates as a team member in planning and organizing information and project activities.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Examples: Personal Productivity: Self Organization and Overcoming Procrastination, Quality Management for Continuous Improvement.Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Can assist others in organization
Skill: Participates in developing streamlined systems to organize and track team/project information and activities. Sets priorities with an appropriate and realistic sense of the time demand involved. Assists others to build their planning & organization skills, and to analyze and evaluate progress towards goals and objectives. Assists others to set priorities to ensure manageable workloads.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Examples: Learning to Say No; Managing Your Time; Time Management Fundamentals and more. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Can assist others in organization
Skill: Participates in developing streamlined systems to organize and track team/project information and activities. Sets priorities with an appropriate and realistic sense of the time demand involved. Competency: Can develop organizational systems for others
Skill: Anticipates and develops new procedures and systems in response to changing priorities. Develops and monitors complex tracking and organizational systems which may substantially affect issue areas and CCETC as a whole. Understands the role of the issue area's organization and planning within the larger CCETC context. Assesses overall CCETC resources, staffing and commitments to allow for manageable workloads.

Competency: Can perform the necessary steps to accomplish program goals
Skill: Understands project goals, the necessary steps to accomplish those goals and one’s role in the project.

Competency: Can perform the necessary steps to accomplish program goals
Skill: Effectively manages time, assignments, and priorities to accomplish project goals, and seeks help as needed.
Resource Description: NLI periodically offers a workshop entitled "Getting Things Done" which helps build skills to effectively manage one's time and set "Smart Goals." Check NLI website for information on upcoming workshops or email <natural.leaders@cornell.edu>.

Competency: Can perform the necessary steps to accomplish program goals
Skill: Effectively manages time, assignments, and priorities to accomplish project goals, and seeks help as needed.

Staff can attend at Family and Children's Services or, if there is enough interest, the programs can be offered on location. (there is a cost- $150 per hour if offered onsite)

Competency: Ability to multitask the leadership of multiple projects.
Skill: Effectively leads multiple simultaneous projects and multiple project teams. Anticipates and manages cascading impacts from changes to any single project. Strategically assesses and plans for potential opportunities, synergies and challeges within and between projects. Modifies project timelines and budgets in response to financial or environmental changes.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Examples: Advanced Tools for Managing Multiple Projects, Managing Projects with Organizations, and more. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Effectively works as part of a team
Skill: Works effectively and respectfully with diverse groups of staff, volunteers and other stakeholders to accomplish goals. Develop goals in collaboration with others. Communicates appropriately and takes action within team as needed. Respects the ideas and opinions of others. Accepts and offers help when needed. Gives and accepts feedback in a positive manner.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Examples: Teamwork Fundamentals; Having Difficult Conversations; Conflict Resolution Fundamentals. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Effectively works as part of a team

Competency: Effectively works as part of a diverse team

Leads others to achieve team goals.

Skill: Efficiently, effectively and positively supervises diverse teams of staff & volunteers . Offers constructive feedback to team members. Assists team members to manage workloads and set/accomplish goals. Ensures accountability. Helps team members develop appropriate professional improvement plans.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Examples: Preparing for Your Review; Delivering Employee Feedback; Mentoring Others. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Skill: Efficiently, effectively and positively supervises diverse teams of staff & volunteers . Offers constructive feedback to team members. Assists team members to manage workloads and set/accomplish goals. Ensures accountability. Helps team members develop appropriate professional improvement plans.

Competency: Can effectively work from home.

Competency: Can effectively work from home.
Skill: Understands Cornell & CCETC policies re: working remotely and appropriately communicates policies to team members and effectively supervises those working off-site.
Resource Description: Supervisor Development Certificate Program is presented in person twice per year in Ithaca (Cornell campus)

Competency: Can resolve conflicts within the team.
Skill: Can solve problems and resolve conflicts that arise in operation of the program.  Is able to effectively mediate conflicts between two or more employees to provide long lasting improvements to team dynamics.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Examples: Preparing for Your Review; Delivering Employee Feedback; Mentoring Others. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Can resolve conflicts within the team.

Competency: Can effectively build and lead a team effort.
Skill: Is able to identify strengths in team members and build effective and collaborative projects, utilizing the diffences of the individuals to the advantage of all.

Resource Description: Multiple webinars on leadership:  Understanding Diverse Personalilities, Making it Work with Diverse Teams, Building Leadership and Developing Communities

Competency: Can provide supervision, guidance and leadership to other supervisors
Skill: Efficiently, effectively and positively assists supervisors to build their skills and develop appropriate professional improvement plans. Identifies or develops adequate resources for supervisor development. Anticipates and plans for emerging supervisory needs and opportunities. Understands best practices for ensuring accountability across the association.
Resource Description: Web-based training videos on many topics. Examples: Coaching and Developing Employees; Mentoring Others. Free to staff with Cornell NetID.

Competency: Can assist staff to plan staff development opportunities.
Skill: Is able to lead staff and team in goal-setting and developing professional improvement plans, utilizing available resources, performance evaluations, and position descriptions.
Resource Description: Employees may attend EAP Seminars on the following topic: Leading the Way with Emotional Intelligence.  Staff can attend at Family and Children's Services or, if there is enough interest, the programs can be offered on location. (there is a cost- $150 per hour if offered onsite)

Competency: Awareness of Personal Strengths and Values
Skill: Knows one personal strengths (e.g., talents) and can use them to achieve desired work outcomes
Resource Description: An online assessment, personalized report and ideas for action that apply a strengths-based model to improving one's effectiveness, engagement and enjoyment at work. Purchasing the book, with an code for the online assessment, is most cost-effective approach.

Competency: Ability to make positive changes.
Skill: Can identify areas for change, create strategies, and implement positive changes in work and personal lives.

Competency: Career Advancement
Skill: Is able to identify a suitable direction for career advancement and create a plan for achieving it.
